Firstly, let us say thank you to Heritage Lottery in Wales for enabling us to bring
you these podcasts.
My name is Jamie Baker and I'm part of Horn Development Association, HDA in Cardiff.
And this site, Black Diverse and Welsh, is intended to bring together lots of initiatives
that we've been involved in in terms of Black and Diverse people in Wales.
But most immediately, a series of episodes, a series of contributions, which are about
Cardiff.
And if you sit outside the Norwegian church on the bay in Cardiff and in better times
have a cup of coffee, hopefully this series of podcasts over the next few months will
give you an idea what that place you're looking at used to be, what's happened there and
what it represents to the people who live or lived in the streets you, to a large extent,
can't see anymore.
This is episode six of the series of podcasts and it's with Richard Ford.
We're recording, so wherever you want to start mate.
OK, right.
My name is Richard Ford.
I'm 61 years of age at this moment in time.
I'm one of nine children, mixed heritage, Caribbean, from Barbados, my grandfather.
My grandfather on my mother's side was from Yemen and the rest of us are mainly Welsh.
I lived in West Coast, which was kind of in between the docks and Tiger Bay.
And I grew up, as I say, one of nine children.
My first memory I come up with pop bottles.
We used to have glass pop bottles and people would ask you to go to the shop or you'd ask
them if they want anything in the shop because you would go in.
And for going in return instead of giving you money, they'd give you bottles to take
back because you got money off them.
So that was helpful to yourself and obviously to the state of the world right now because
now we're using too much plastic.
Timber floats, right?
There was a place called the timber floats.
They used to have logs in that and in water basically and we used to go fishing over there
with my brothers.
Basically, my brother used to take me out of the house because I was like four or five
and I'd sit on the riverbank.
And on two occasions I went fishing with him.
I fell in.
So that was another memory that stuck in my mind.
In West Coast we had this place called the Patch outside everyone's house.
It's kind of built in a circle.
It's still there now, right at this moment, but they have built gardens on it, which is
not the same as it was obviously back in the day.
We used to be able to, in winter, throw ice, throw water on the Patch to make ice so we'd
have slides.
That was a great fun and didn't cost anything and didn't hurt anybody, hurt yourselves.
Teenagers, teenage life, we used to go to Top Rank, which was in town, and we used to
go to Under 18's Discos.
So that was on a Tuesday evening and Saturday morning.

and we'd all walk home or we'd meet outside and in a place called Caroline Street so everyone
could kind of get back home, down to the bay, safely.
